Cryptic peptides are bioactive amino acid sequences hidden in a precursor protein, which are formed and released when a peptidase cleaves the parent protein at specific cleavage sites
1 . Some cryptic peptides are present also in the brain (neuropeptides, NPs), where they play an important role in the modulation of various processes, such as neuronal signalling, angiogenesis, inflammatory response, immune response, and cell growth
2 . Cryptic peptides may have biological properties and activities that are distinct from their parent proteins
